title.rendered: What is an NFT?  Examples, costs and explanation of the term digital |  Geeky Entertainment

content.rendered:
Expendable and non-expendable property

To understand what an NFT is, you have to know that there are fungible and non-fungible goods in the economic system. Expendable goods have a certain value, but can be exchanged. For example, a note can be exchanged for another with the same value and the owner still owns a certain amount.

Non-expendable assets are those that have value, but are irreplaceable. A work of art, a historical relic, or a signed trading card are examples of non-expendable property, as they cannot be exchanged for the same.

Non-expendable property may have a monetary value, but there is no other item like it in the world and its authenticity can be verified by experts. These goods are usually sold with a certificate of authenticity and that is why they are so valuable.

NFT stands for Non Fungible Token or non-fungible voucher; that is, irreplaceable. However, an NFT is not a physical asset.

NFTs have a close relationship with cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin. Cryptocurrencies and NFTs belong to the blockchain system, a digital business model that securely records digital transactions.

An NFT is also known as a crypto art since the transactions work in a similar way to cryptocurrencies; however, in the digital world, a cryptocurrency is the equivalent of a bill (fungible good) and an NFT is equivalent to a work of art (non-fungible good).

This means that an NFT is a unique and irreplaceable item that does not have a replica; however, the owner does not own it in a tangible way, but obtains a digital ownership certificate. This certificate is validated by the blockchain system with metadata that cannot be duplicated, as it guarantees its authenticity, value and transaction history.

In this way, just like a piece of art, the owner of an NFT can sell their digital asset at any time to another person and its value could increase over the years.

Examples and price of an NFT

More and more people are joining the trend of selling or acquiring NFTs, but, just like art exhibitions or collectibles, there are elements that are more famous and valuable than others.

In March 2021, Jack Dorsey, the founder of Twitter, sold his first NFT-certified tweet for $2.9 million. Anyone can take a screenshot of the tweet and even print it out; however, there is only one digital certificate for the tweet that verifies it as NFT.

Singer Grimes collaborated with a crypto art site to sell $6 million worth of musical and graphic works. Recently, kanye-west he also ventured into the world of NFTs with a collection called ‘The books of Ye’.

In March 2021, an auction house sold a Beeple digital work for $69 million, making it the most expensive NFT ever, to date.

There are artists who have merged physical pieces with digital ones and when selling a tangible work they accompany it with a digital certificate that secures it as an NFT or gives them an extra digital element.

Not all NFTs cost millions of dollars. More and more people are selling certified digital pieces for less money; However, it is important to keep in mind that the blockchain system is not cheap to maintain, so even if they do not reach a millionaire value, NFTs can cost thousands of dollars.

Who gives the value to NFTs?

People and artists are the ones who give value to digital and physical pieces. There are those who do not find it logical to pay millions of dollars for a digital work that can never be touched, just as there are those who do not find it logical to pay millions of dollars for a pair of sneakers or a Michael Jordan T-shirt.

There are people who see it as a passing trend and others as a scam; however, with the rise of cryptocurrencies, there are people who consider the purchase of NFTs as an investment, speculating that their value could increase over the years.
